awd_titl_txt: IOS Proposal: RUI: Exploring range limits in the fiddler crab Uca pugnax using the Dynamic Energy Budget approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine intertidal invertebrates contend with daily cycles of submergence and exposure. As the planet warms, increases in both sea water and air temperature will impact the fitness of these fringe dwellers.  This investigation uses Dynamic Energy Budget (DEB) modelling to investigate the impact of food availability and body temperature in both air and water on the energy budget of the mud fiddler crab, Uca pugnax, an abundant and impactful ecosystem engineer. In 2014 mud fiddler crabs appeared for the first time in the salt marshes of New Hampshire, 80 km north of its previous northern range limit, and it is expected to continue to spread north as the north Atlantic warms. This species will have a large impact on the ecosystems it invades because it forms dense colonies that often exceed 100 individuals/m2 and is an intense bioturbator and generalist consumer of infaunal prey. A model will be developed to predict the energetic trade-offs made by mud fiddler crabs under different food and body temperature conditions, which in turn impacts where it can survive and reproduce. This model will be useful for predicting future species ranges for mud fiddler crabs and other intertidal species under different warming scenarios.

In the first year of this study, field and laboratory investigations will be conducted across the current species range to determine standard DEB budget parameters, including the shape coefficient, Arrhenias temperatures in air and water, ingestion and assimilation rates, maintenance costs, energy reserves, structural energy content, and the costs of growth. The model will be modified for bimodal breathing, a trait shared by thousands of species living at the sea-land interface, as well as some freshwater species, like lungfish and amphibians. Furthermore, a thermoregulatory correction factor will be developed for the model to explore the energetic costs caused by interruptions in feeding on very hot days when crabs retreat to burrows to avoid overheating. In the second and third years, the DEB model will be developed, tested and applied to questions about energetic constraints and tradeoffs under different environmental conditions and the implications of bimodal breathing for thermal tolerance. This grant will fund academic year and summer research opportunities, as well as, training in mathematical biology for 6-8 undergraduates for each year of the grant from Mount Holyoke College, a primarily undergraduate institution serving women.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Anthropogenic climate change is impacting marine invertebrate species worldwide, some of which are responding with range shifts. This is true of the Atlantic marsh fiddler crab, an ecologically impactful species whose historical northern range edge ended just north of Cape Cod, Massachusetts, USA, but now can be found on the coastal mudflats of central Maine. This species is expanding north faster than other intertidal crabs in the northeastern United States. We want to understand how physiology and thermoregulatory behaviors influence where the marsh fiddler can exist. For this grant, we collected parameter estimates for energetics modeling to predict how environmental temperatures impact physiology and behaviors, which in turn affect the ability of the marsh fiddler crab to invest in reproduction across its historical and current range. 

We found that the marsh fiddler crab actively resisted warming in its environment with behavioral thermoregulation. For every 1 C increase in the surface temperature in their natural environments, crabs experienced a 0.70-0.77 C increase in body temperature. Crabs resisted body warming by using their burrows, which can be up to 20 C cooler than the surface. We found that the body temperature that crabs began to use burrows to thermoregulate was around 24 C, which is far below the critical body temperatures that lead to death (around 40 C). Many crabs experienced body temperatures of 24 C early in the reproductive season, several months before the hottest days of the year. Because the use of burrows involves fitness trade-offs--crabs cooling off in their burrows cannot feed or attract mates-- these results suggest that warming temperatures in the historical species range could begin to impact crabs far earlier in the year than expected.

 Like all organisms, the marsh fiddler has an optimal temperature range for all activities, and we determined this range with laboratory-based measurements. We found that both male and female crabs showed significantly depressed respiration rates and running speeds when temperatures dipped to 15 C. Between 20 C and 35 C, female respiration rates were higher and did not vary significantly, although their running speeds increased. Males showed more typical performance curves, with peaks at 25 C for respiration rate and 30 C for running speed. Finally, we allowed individual males and females to roam freely in a mesocosm with a sandy bottom and a temperature gradient ranging from 15-40 C. We measured body temperatures after one hour with the assumption that crabs would be the temperature that they preferred. These preferred body temperatures were 23 C for males and 25 C for females, very close to the 24 C seen for the thermoregulatory response in the field-based crabs and the 25 C peak for thermal performance in males measured in the laboratory.

Finally, our field-based video recordings of crab behaviors, along with laboratory-based body cooling measurements, provided specific details on how crabs use burrows in attempts to maintain preferred/optimal body temperatures. We found that surface-active crabs began to use their burrows more as the surface became hotter; however, burrow stays tended to be short, usually under five minutes, regardless of the surface temperature. The laboratory-based body cooling experiments, wherein crabs with an implanted thermocouple were allowed to retreat to burrows to cool down, demonstrated that these short stays cooled crabs but were too short for them to come to equilibrium with burrow temperatures.  Crabs retreat to burrows for multiple reasons--to hide from predators, mate, rehydrate, and thermoregulate. We found that surface active thermoregulating crabs remained underground for just the time it took to cool down. 

The insights we have acquired through this grant shed light on how temperature impacts the behavior and physiological performance of the Atlantic marsh fiddler crab. We now know this species prefers body temperatures between 23-25 C, likely because these temperatures are good for performance. Furthermore, we know that they try to keep their bodies within this preferred range by retreating to burrows that are cooler than the surface. However, time spent in burrows cooling down reduces opportunities for other vital activities like feeding and courtship, and burrow stays are short. The marsh fiddler is now found in central Maine, where cooler temperatures shorten the duration of their active season. The data we are currently collecting on seasonal fat stores and investment in gonads and embryos will further reveal the impacts of temperature on fitness in the historical and shifted range. 

Sixteen undergraduate students and the PI, all from underrepresented groups in STEM, did the work supported by this grant. At the time of this report, most of these students were pursuing or planning to pursue graduate work in STEM-related fields. The approaches and findings from this work were also used in educational programming for the Bard Microcollege, a community-based educational program for young mothers with limited financial resources, and the Shutesbury Elementary School.
